Deep Nets with Subsampling Layers Unwittingly Discard Useful Activations at Test-Time

Chiao-An Yang 11 â€ƒâ€ƒ Ziwei Liu 22 â€ƒâ€ƒ Raymond A. Yeh 11
Abstract

Subsampling layers play a crucial role in deep nets by discarding a portion of an activation map to reduce its spatial dimensions. This encourages the deep net to learn higher-level representations. Contrary to this motivation, we hypothesize that the discarded activations are useful and can be incorporated on the fly to improve modelsâ€™ prediction. To validate our hypothesis, we propose a search and aggregate method to find useful activation maps to be used at test time. We applied our approach to the task of image classification and semantic segmentation. Extensive experiments over nine different architectures on multiple datasets show that our method consistently improves model test-time performance, complementing existing test-time augmentation techniques. Our code is available at https://github.com/ca-joe-yang/discard-in-subsampling.

1 Introduction

In computer vision, deep nets are commonly trained with the assumption that data samples are drawn independently and identically from an unknown distributionÂ [42]. Following this assumption, it is intuitive that the same model,Â i.e., same forward pass, should be applied to all samples during both the training and testing time. However, when the assumption is not met then changing the test time procedure may lead to better performance. For example, test-time augmentation (TTA) leverages additional prior information, i.e., knowing the suitable augmentations, over the data distribution to improve model performance. For vision models, TTA methods apply random augmentations,Â e.g., random crops, flips, and rotation, to the test image and perform majority voting to make a final predictionÂ [55, 54, 17, 46, 70]. With the success of TTA, a natural question arises: are there other choices for modifying the test-time procedure?

In this work, we present an orthogonal approach to improving the model performance at test-time. Instead of imposing additional knowledge through data augmentation, we re-examine the ones that are built into the deep net architecture. We focus on the knowledge built into subsampling and pooling layers. Our observation is that models with subsampling layers do not utilize activations to their fullest, as some activations are discarded. A question arises, can the discharged activations benefit the model? The main challenges are: (a) identifying which of the discarded activations are useful; and (b) how to incorporate these activations into a test-time procedure.

We formulate an activations search space for a given pre-trained deep net. Each state in this space corresponds to an activations map that can be extracted by choosing different selection indices (sğ‘ sitalic_s) in the subsampling layers. Given a computation budget, we conduct a greedy search for the set of most promising activation maps based on a confidence criterion. We then aggregate these activation maps using a weighted average to make a final prediction.

We conduct extensive experiments on ImageNetÂ [25] over nine different pre-trained networks, including ConvNets and Vision Transformers, to validate the efficacy of the proposed approach. We also evaluate our method on the task of semantic segmentation using CityscapesÂ [11] and ADE20KÂ [77] with different segmentation networks, including FCNÂ [36], DeepLabÂ [7, 8], and SegFormerÂ [66]. Overall, we find that our test-time procedure improves both classification and segmentation performance. Additionally, our approach achieves additional gains when it is used in conjunction with existing TTA methods, i.e., our approach complements TTA.

Our contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We identified that deep nets with subsampling layers discard activations that could be useful for prediction.

  • â€¢

    We propose a framework to search over the discarded activations with a learned criterion and aggregate useful ones, via an attention aggregation module, to improve model performance at test-time.

  • â€¢

    Extensive experiments on various deep nets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed test-time procedure on both image classification and semantic segmentation tasks.

2 Related work

We briefly discuss related work in test-time augmentation, adaptation, ensemble models, and pooling layers.

Test-time augmentation. As our approach can be viewed as a form of Test-Time Augmentation (TTA) but over the set of selection indices, hence we briefly review TTA. At a high level, TTA aims to increase a modelâ€™s performance at test-time by at the cost of computation increases. This is beneficial for tasks where the risk of making a mistake significantly outweighs the computationÂ e.g., medical-related tasks. We note that the computation increase may be very significant. Letâ€™s consider image classification on ImageNet, TTA applied to their model includes 144 crops per-imageÂ [55], i.e., an increase 144Ã—\timesÃ— in compute. More recent TTA methodÂ [52], further increases the computation to 150Ã—150\times150 Ã—.

The most common form of TTA is to augment the input image and combine the output from each augmentation to make a final prediction for improving task performance. Common augmentations include random croppingÂ [55, 54, 4], flippingÂ [17, 46], or combinations of the augmentationsÂ [41]. SeeÂ Fig.Â 1 for a comparison of standard, test-time augmentation, and our test-time procedure.

Recent worksÂ [23, 38, 52, 10, 31, 41, 16] try to learn the distribution of data augmentation for test-time impacts. Given a set of TTA augmentation, a common approach is to average the resulting logits to make a final prediction. GPSÂ [38] learns to pick the top-kğ‘˜kitalic_k augmentation transforms based on an iterative greedy search. Â Shanmugam etÂ al. [52] learn a weighted function, deciding which augmentation transform is more important than the other. Â Chun etÂ al. [10] also studied how to effectively combine/aggregate augmentationsâ€™ output into a single prediction via the Entropy Weight Method (EWM)Â [32, 3],Â i.e., the final prediction is a weighted combination based on entropy. DiffTPTÂ [14] leverages diffusion models to generate high-quality augmented data. TeSLAÂ [57] introduced flipped cross-entropy loss to adapt the pre-trained model during test time.Â Kim etÂ al. [23] learn to select designated data transformation for each image by introducing an auxiliary module on estimating losses. Unfortunately, we are not able to reproduce their resultsÂ [23] due to its heavy computation requirement.

It is to be noted that our method differs from the aforementioned works in several ways. First, all TTA methods modify the inputs on the image space using various data transformations. On the other hand, we use the discarded activations in the feature space of the subsampling layers. Second, unlike these TTA methods that learn general domain knowledge, our searching and aggregation procedure adapts to each image and generates an instance-based augmented feature. Finally, our learned aggregation can be generalized to different test-time budgets without the need for retraining. In contrast, existing worksÂ [38, 52] need to retrain their aggregation layer if they change the test-time budget.

Ensemble methods. Classical ensemble methods such as stackingÂ [63] and baggingÂ [6] aggregate predictions from multiple models to create an improved prediction. Recent worksÂ [61, 43, 74, 21] focus on how to efficiently learn a set of diverse models. We note that ensemble models require training multiple models and running each of them at test time. On the contrary, our approach only requires a single pre-trained model (with subsampling layers) to make a prediction. In other words, our approach is orthogonal to the ensemble methods. If the ensembled deep nets contain subsampling layers, then we can apply our approach on top of it.

Subsampling and pooling layers. Subsampling layers can be traced back to the origin of convolutional neural networksÂ [15, 27] where striding is used to reduce the spatial dimension and increase the networksâ€™ receptive field. Another choice to reduce the spatial dimension is pooling layers, e.g., Average PoolingÂ [26], Max-PoolingÂ [69, 47], or other generalizationsÂ [51, 72, 53, 48]. To preserve the lost information from downsampling layers, anti-aliased CNNÂ [73] inserts a max-blur-pool layer to the pooling layer. In this work, we show that deep nets with subsampling layers can improve their test-time performance by using discarded activations. Additional relevant details and notation of subsampling layers are reviewed inÂ Sec.Â 3.

We provide a brief review of the subsampling layer and how it is used in deep nets. For readability, we describe these ideas on 1D â€œimagesâ€, in practice, they are generalized to 2D activation maps with multiple channels.

Deep nets with subsampling layers. Many deep nets in computer vision contain subsampling layers to reduce spatial dimensions. We take a very generic view toward subsampling layers. Consider a convolution layer with stride two, it can be viewed as a convolution layer with stride one followed by a subsampling by a factor of two. Similarly, any pooling operation can be decomposed into a â€œslidingâ€ operation followed by subsampling. For example, max pooling is equivalent to a sliding max filter followed by a subsampling layer. With this perspective, many notable deep net architectures contain subsampling layers, including early works such as LeNetÂ [27], the popular ResNetÂ [18], MobileNetÂ [20, 50, 19], and the recent vision transformers (ViTs)Â [13, 34, 33].

4 Our Approach

Given a trained deep net with subsampling layers, we develop a test-time procedure that improves model performance. The approach is motivated by the observation that subsampling layers discard activations, e.g., a subsampling factor of two on a 2D feature map leads to losing 3434\frac{3}{4}divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG of the spatial activations. As these discarded activations contain information about the input image, we believe they can be incorporated at test-time to improve model performance.

The idea is to keep a subset of the discarded activations and aggregate them into an improved prediction. To do so, we need to answer the following:

  1. (a)

    How to better aggregate the activations? Using all test-time transformations is not always a good ideaÂ [38, 52]. Similarly, simply averaging all discarded activations leads to degraded performance.

  2. (b)

    Which of the discarded activations to retain? Naively keeping all the discarded activations leads to an exponential growth in the number of feature maps which is impractical.

To address (a), inÂ Sec.Â 4.1, we describe how we learn an aggregation function based on the attention mechanism. To address (b), inÂ Sec.Â 4.2, we discuss how the learned attention values can be used as a search criterion for finding useful discarded activations. An overview of the proposed aggregate and search framework is visually illustrated inÂ Fig.Â 1(b).

4.1 Aggregating selected activations for prediction

Learning an aggregation function. We propose a learnable multi-head attention module to be the aggregation function for two reasons: (a) The importance of one feature ğ’‡ğ’”subscriptğ’‡ğ’”{\bm{f}}_{\bm{s}}bold_italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is relative to other features. (b) An attention module is a set operatorÂ [28] that can take an input of variable size for the feature set â„±â„±{\mathcal{F}}caligraphic_F. In other words, the aggregation function can be trained on one fixed budget and evaluated at any arbitrary testing budget. Contrarily, the learned aggregation function proposed byÂ Shanmugam etÂ al. [52] is retrained for each test-time budget.

Learning-free aggregation. Inspired byÂ Chun etÂ al. [10], we use the entropy of the logits to quantify the confidence of the model in its prediction and weight each activation accordingly. 4.2 Searching for useful activations

We have described how we aggregated a set of features ğ’®^^ğ’®\hat{\mathcal{S}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG. In this section, we will describe how to find this set of indices where the corresponding activations would benefit the model performance from the discarded set ğ’®\{0}\ğ’®0{\mathcal{S}}\backslash\{0\}caligraphic_S \ { 0 }. As its size |ğ’®|ğ’®|{\mathcal{S}}|| caligraphic_S | grows exponentially with the number of subsampling layers, naively iterating for all activations would be expensive. To address this, we propose a greedy search to gradually grow a set of selected activations within a given compute budget BOurssubscriptğµOursB_{\texttt{Ours}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The high-level idea of the search algorithm is summarized inÂ Alg.Â 1 and visualized inÂ Fig.Â 4.
Search procedure. We formulate the task of finding a set of promising

activation maps ğ’®^^ğ’®\hat{\mathcal{S}}over^ start_ARG caligraphic_S end_ARG as a search problem over the state space ğ’®=âˆl=1L{0,â€¦,R(l)âˆ’1}ğ’®superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘™1ğ¿0â€¦superscriptğ‘…ğ‘™1{\mathcal{S}}=\prod_{l=1}^{L}\{0,\dots,R^{(l)}-1\}caligraphic_S = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT { 0 , â€¦ , italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 } where each state ğ’”=(s1,s2,â€¦,sL)ğ’”subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ¿{\bm{s}}=(s_{1},s_{2},\dots,s_{L})bold_italic_s = ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) corresponds to a tuple of selection index for each of the subsampling layer lğ‘™litalic_l in the pre-trained deep net. The Search, inÂ Alg.Â 1, returns all the states it has visited within a computation budget Bğš˜ğšğš›ğšœsubscriptğµğš˜ğšğš›ğšœB_{\tt ours}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

To implement this search, we utilize a priority queue Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q (lowest values are popped first) to determine which of the following states is more promising to visit next. The priority queue is sorted based on the values computed from a Criterionâ¢(ğ’‡ğ’”)Criterionsubscriptğ’‡ğ’”\texttt{Criterion}({\bm{f}}_{\bm{s}})Criterion ( bold_italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) function. Later in this section, we describe our proposed learned and learning-free criteria.

For each visited state ğ’”ğ’”{\bm{s}}bold_italic_s, we then add its â€œneighboring statesâ€ for a subsampling layer lğ‘™litalic_l. We define the neighbors of state ğ’”=ğŸğ’”0{\bm{s}}=\mathbf{0}bold_italic_s = bold_0 at the 0thsuperscript0th0^{\text{th}}0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT layer is the set âˆªiâˆˆ(1,2,â€¦â¢R(0)){(i,0,0,â€¦)}subscriptğ‘–12â€¦superscriptğ‘…0ğ‘–00â€¦\cup_{i\in(1,2,\dots R^{(0)})}\{(i,0,0,\dots)\}âˆª start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ ( 1 , 2 , â€¦ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ( italic_i , 0 , 0 , â€¦ ) }. The expanded layer lğ‘™litalic_l is selected in a top-down fashion. Finally, we use a dictionary Eğ¸Eitalic_E to keep track of the expanded layers for each state to avoid redundancies.

Learned criterion. We prioritize expanding the node with the highest attention score from the attention ğ‘¾ğ‘¾{\bm{W}}bold_italic_W in Eq.Â (5) since the correspondent feature contributes the most in the final aggregated feature. Thus, we choose

Extension to semantic segmentation. To extend the classification formulation to semantic segmentation, we view semantic segmentation as a per-pixel classification problem. For example, the entropy will then be computed for each pixel location. To aggregate the selected activations, we compute a per-pixel weight map for each activation instead of a scalar weight for the entire activation map.

5 Experiments

To validate the proposed test-time procedure, we conduct experiments on two computer vision tasks: image classification, and semantic segmentation. In the following, we provide the experiment setup and implementation details before discussing the results.

5.1 Image classification

Experiment setup. Recent TTA methods on image classification focus on learning TTA. Hence, we focus on comparison using the learned aggregation and criterion from our approach. The results of our learning-free version are included in the appendix.

We evaluate our learned methods on two image classification datasets, namely ImageNetÂ [25] and Flowers102Â [44]. We provide experiments on additional datasetsÂ [24] in the appendix. For ImageNet, we use the pre-trained weights released by Pytorch. We randomly selected 20,000 and 5,000 images from train of ImageNet to be used for training and validation of the aggregation function. We report results on the val set of ImageNet. For Flowers102, we fine-tune the pre-trained ImageNet weights from Pytorch on Flowers102 using the official training/validation/testing split for Flowers102. For both ImageNet and Flowers102, each image is first resized to 256px and cropped to 224px.

Please note, this experiment setup differs fromÂ Shanmugam etÂ al. [52] as their setup is non-conventional.Â Shanmugam etÂ al. [52] resplit ImageNetâ€™s val set into train/validation/test sets. In other words, their models are trained on a subset of ImageNetâ€™s original val set. They also reported non-conventional â€œmultiple runsâ€. For each â€œrunâ€, they evaluate the same trained model over different test subsets splits, where each split is sampled (with replacement) from their ImageNetâ€™s test split111Please see their codeÂ github.com/divyashan/test-time-augmentation) at ğšğšğš’ğš•ğšœ/ğšğšŸğšŠğš•ğšğšŠğšğš.ğš™ğš¢:ğ™»ğŸ»ğŸ¾\tt{utils/evaluate.py}:L58typewriter_utils / typewriter_evaluate . typewriter_py : typewriter_L58.. Instead of following the unconventional setup, we conduct experiments using their released code on standard val split for each of the datasets. For multiple runs, each experiment is repeated 5 times with different random seeds, where the training split is resampled, and the aggregation module is reinitialization. Overall, we observe the standard deviations for our method to be less than 0.05%.

Implementation details. FollowingÂ Shanmugam etÂ al. [52], we choose ResNet18, ResNet50Â [18], MobileNetV2Â [50], and InceptionV3Â [56] to test the generalizability of our procedure on multiple backbones. Please refer to the supplementary for our definition of FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and CÏ•subscriptğ¶italic-Ï•C_{\phi}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and more results on additional backbones, e.g. ResNext50Â [67], ShuffleNetV2Â [39], SwinÂ [34], and SwinV2Â [33].

To train our aggregation module Ağ´Aitalic_A, we fix the budget BourssubscriptğµoursB_{\texttt{ours}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 30 during training. To encourage the model to expand unseen nodes rather than focusing on seen ones, during training, we randomly sampled the nodes with probability inverse-correlated to its Criterion. We use the AdamW optimizerÂ [37] and the cosine-annealing scheduler. The initial learning rate on ImageNet and Flowers102 is set to 1â¢eâˆ’61superscriptğ‘’61e^{-6}1 italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.The training batch sizes are 32 for all datasets.

Baselines. For baselines, we select several state-of-the-art TTA methods, namely GPSÂ [38], AugTTAÂ [52], and ClassTTAÂ [52]. For a fair comparison, each method is evaluated under the same test-time budget BtotalsubscriptğµtotalB_{\texttt{total}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., the number of total forward passes required to generate the final outputs.

Both baseline TTA methods and our procedure required their test-time budget. We denote the former one as BttasubscriptğµttaB_{\texttt{tta}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the latter one as BourssubscriptğµoursB_{\texttt{ours}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since the baseline TTA methods and ours are independent of each other, the overall budget BtotalsubscriptğµtotalB_{\texttt{total}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the product of BttasubscriptğµttaB_{\texttt{tta}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and BourssubscriptğµoursB_{\texttt{ours}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, when comparing under the budget Btotal=150subscriptğµtotal150B_{\texttt{total}}=150italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 150 inÂ Tab.Â 1, (Btta,Bours)=(150,1)subscriptğµttasubscriptğµours1501(B_{\texttt{tta}},B_{\texttt{ours}})=(150,1)( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( 150 , 1 ) is selected for the experiments w/o Ours, while (Btta,Bours)=(10,15)subscriptğµttasubscriptğµours1015(B_{\texttt{tta}},B_{\texttt{ours}})=(10,15)( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( 10 , 15 ) is selected for the experiments w/ Ours. Please refer to the supplementary for more detailed configuration.

We follow the expanded TTA policy settingsÂ [52] and build a TTA pool containing various data transformations, such as Flip, Colorization, or Blur. The original expanded policyÂ [52] fixes BttasubscriptğµttaB_{\texttt{tta}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at 128. We increase the possible range of BttasubscriptğµttaB_{\texttt{tta}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for expanded policy to cover up to 1000. Please refer to supplementary for the detailed policy.

Comparision to TTA. We report the comparison between the baseline TTA methods with and without ours inÂ Tab.Â 1 andÂ 2 on ImageNet and Flowers102 respectively.

We report the performance under Btotal=subscriptğµtotalabsentB_{\texttt{total}}=italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 30, 100, and 150 inÂ Tab.Â 1. We observe that the baseline TTA methods do not scale well when increasing BtotalsubscriptğµtotalB_{\texttt{total}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The performance of GPS remains the same since the number of budget is fixed in their design; the gains on AugTTA are often minuscule or slightly negative; while ClassTTA usually suffers from using more budget due to its difficulty in converging. Our approach instead achieves consistent gain when using higher BtotalsubscriptğµtotalB_{\texttt{total}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, ours outperforms its counterpart in all cases. On average, we improve the top-1 Acc. of TTA baselines by 0.87%. Specifically, we improve GPS on average by 0.32%, ClassTTA by 2.01%, and AugTTA by 0.19%.

InÂ Tab.Â 2, we report the performance under the same settings on Flowers102. The baseline TTA methods do not benefit much from using more BtotalsubscriptğµtotalB_{\texttt{total}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT total end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our approach outperforms its counterpart in most cases while remaining competitive in the rest. For example, we achieved the top-1 Acc. over all baselines by 0.57%.

Ablation study. We conduct ablation studies using ResNet-18 as the base architecture and report the performance of our method in our validation split of ImageNet without any TTA. We use BourssubscriptğµoursB_{\texttt{ours}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT=30 in these studies since the difference between different choices can be minuscule when the budget is small and the searching process is short.

InÂ Tab.Â 3, we test other choices for searching the space ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}caligraphic_S inÂ Alg.Â 1: line 8. Specifically, we consider limiting the search space {1,â‹¯,L}1â‹¯ğ¿\{1,\cdots,L\}{ 1 , â‹¯ , italic_L } by considering fewer layers. We ablate by removing the expansion on the first layer (l=1ğ‘™1l=1italic_l = 1). We hypothesize that the layer has a small offset and therefore should have little impact on final outputs. On the other hand, we can omit the expansion on the last layer (l=Lğ‘™ğ¿l=Litalic_l = italic_L) because the large alignment necessary from the aggregation deteriorates the quality of the activations. Limiting the search space also greatly decreases the latency of our approach due to faster spatial alignment.

Overall, we observe that it is beneficial to limit the search space for better performance and faster speed. Overall, we find out that top-down search while omitting the last layer has the best performance in image classification. We choose to omit both the first and last layer as our default option because it balances between good performance and fast latency.

InÂ Tab.Â 4, we consider other aggregation methods besides our proposed one inÂ Eq.Â (6). The baseline is to simply average all activations. We report the performance of training-free aggregation by entropy-weighting inÂ Eq.Â (8). Finally, we ablate the Align inÂ Eq.Â (6) to show the importance of aligning feature maps before aggregation. Our proposed learned aggregation yields the best performance. Additionally, without aligning feature maps, the performance drops significantly by 0.36% in top-1 accuracy.

InÂ Tab.Â 5, we test other choices for Criterion, determining which ğ’”â€²superscriptğ’”â€²{\bm{s}}^{\prime}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to expand first inÂ Alg.Â 1. The baseline is to expand purely by random. One can suggest choosing ğ’”â€²superscriptğ’”â€²{\bm{s}}^{\prime}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT based on the offsets Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” (seeÂ Eq.Â (10)). We show that expanding the ğ’”â€²superscriptğ’”â€²{\bm{s}}^{\prime}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the lowest entropy (most confident prediction) is competitive when training is not feasible. Using learned attention ğ‘¾ğ‘¾{\bm{W}}bold_italic_W from the aggregation module as the criterion yields the best performance.

Analysis on budget BourssubscriptğµoursB_{\texttt{ours}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. 5.2 Semantic segmentation

Experiment setup. As semantic segmentation has not been studied in learned TTA baselinesÂ [38, 52], we consider the non-learned TTA setting for this section. We conduct experiments using the non-learned version of our approach on CityScapes and ADE20K datasetsÂ [11, 76, 77]. We test on several semantic segmentation backbones and decoders, including ResNetsÂ [18], MobileNetsÂ [20], FCNÂ [36], DeepLabÂ [7, 8], and MiT+SegFormerÂ [66].

Implementation details. Our implementation is based on MMSeg (OpenMMLab Segmentation)Â [40]. It provides pre-trained weights and benchmarks on CityscapesÂ [11] and ADE20kÂ [76, 77]. As for the searching strategy, different from the observation in image classification, we do not find it beneficial to limit the search space ofÂ Alg.Â 1. All search spaces remain unchanged as {1,2,â‹¯,L}12â‹¯ğ¿\{1,2,\cdots,L\}{ 1 , 2 , â‹¯ , italic_L }. For evaluation metrics, we report the mIoU score on both datasets.

Results. InÂ Tab.Â 6, we report the results on Cityscapes and ADE20K semantic segmentation. We test with various combinations of encoder backbones and decoders for semantic segmentation to show that our method generalizes over architectures, including both conv. backbonesÂ (MobileNet, ResNet-50) and transformerÂ (MiT) backbones.

We observe that our approach improves the performance over baseline models on all combinations of encoder backbones and decoders. The largest performance gains are 0.51 on Cityscapes mIoU with MiT + SegFormer (Bours=10subscriptğµours10B_{\texttt{ours}}=10italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10) and 0.27 on ADE20K mIoU with MiT + SegFormer (Bours=4subscriptğµours4B_{\texttt{ours}}=4italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 4). These experiments show that our method can be extended to semantic segmentation with consistent improvements.

Comparison to TTA. InÂ Tab.Â 6, we also report the comparison to HorizotalFlip, which is a popular choice for TTA on semantic segmentation. Our test-time procedure further improves the performance when TTA is used. We observe a 0.30 gain in mIoU on MiT+Segformer (Bours=4subscriptğµours4B_{\texttt{ours}}=4italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 4). The results show that our approach is orthogonal to TTA.

We provide additional results on various segmentation backbones in the appendix, e.g. MobileNetV3+LRASPPÂ [19], UNetÂ [49], SwinÂ [34], UperNetÂ [65], and TwinsÂ [9].

5.3 Discussion & limitation

On both image classification and semantic segmentation, our proposed test-time procedure consistently demonstrates improvements over the baselines on a wide range of deep net architectures. We further point out that the achieved gains are considered significant in image classification and segmentation. However, the improved performance does come at a cost.

The limitation common among all test-time procedures is the increase in test-time computation. Multiple forward passes are needed to make a final prediction, and our method is no different. The increase in test-time computation means that the approach is not suitable for applications with real-time or low-power constraints. On the flip side, our method will be desirable for tasks where the accuracy is substantially more important than the compute time,Â e.g., medical-related tasks. For these tasks, we believe our method is an appealing option to further improve performance.

6 Conclusion

We propose a test-time procedure that leverages the activation maps originally discarded by the subsampling layers. By solving a search problem to identify useful activations and then aggregating them together, via a learned aggregation module and criterion, the model can make more accurate predictions at test-time. On image classification and semantic segmentation tasks, we show that our approach is effective over nine different architectures. Additionally, it complements existing test-time augmentation approaches. These results suggest that our approach is a compelling method in addition to the existing testing TTA framework, especially for tasks that do not have real-time constraints.

A1.2 Learned TTA methods

A different TTA policy. We conduct additional experiments following another TTA policy setting proposed byÂ Shanmugam etÂ al. [52],Â i.e., the standard TTA policy. The standard TTA consists of the following data transformations: Flip, Scale, and FiveCrop. The original standard policy fixes BttasubscriptğµttaB_{\texttt{tta}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at 30. We increase the possible range of BttasubscriptğµttaB_{\texttt{tta}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for standard policy to cover up to 190. Please refer toÂ Sec.Â A3.2 for the details.

We report the comparison between the baseline TTA methods with and without our learned approach inÂ Tab.Â A1 andÂ Tab.Â A2 on ImageNet and Flowers102 respectively. We observe that, unlike our approach, the performance of TTA baselines is highly dependent on the TTA policy. Although the standard policy improves the performance of TTA baselines, our approach shows a consistent gain over them, except for InceptionV3 with AugTTA. As shown inÂ Tab.Â A1, on average, we improve the top-1 Acc. of TTA baselines by 0.9% on ImageNet. Our approach improves GPS on average by 0.4%, ClassTTA by 2.5%, and AugTTA by 0.1%. As shown inÂ Tab.Â A2, on average, we improve the top-1 Acc. of TTA baselines by 0.6% on Flowers102. Specifically, Our approach improves GPS on average by 0.1%, ClassTTA by 1.3%, and AugTTA by 0.2%.

More architectures. InÂ Tab.Â A3, we report the comparison of our learned approach to baseline TTA methods on more architectures, including ResNext50Â [67], ShuffleNetV2Â [39], SwinÂ [34], and SwinV2Â [33]. Specifically, we use these variants from torchvisionÂ [45]: resnext50_32x4d for ResNext50, shufflenet_v2_x1_0 for ShuffleNetV2, swin_t for Swin, and swin_v2_t for SwinV2. We observe consistent gain across all the models on ImageNet.

Computation budget. We compare the computation budget (MACs, and latency) on an image of resolution 224px by 224px between ours and baseline methods. We measure the latency (ms/img) from end-to-end over 10 runs on an Nvidia A6000 GPU. We report the results of ResNet18 inÂ Tab.Â A4 and MobileNetV2 inÂ Tab.Â A5. While GPSÂ [38] has less budget and latency, it does not achieve the best performance and does not scale with a higher budget as shown in the previous experiments. In terms of MACs, our approach requires more operations than ClassTTAÂ [52] and AugTTAÂ [52] on a lower budget. However, since our approach operates on downsampling layers only and shares most computation on non-downsampling layers, the overall latency is more or less similar to theirs.

A1.3 Non-learned TTA methods

For non-learned TTA methods, we followÂ Shanmugam etÂ al. [52] and compared the MeanTTA and MaxTTA aggregation methods. MeanTTA computes the average over all the augmented logits, while MaxTTA picks the highest logit value for each class over all the augmented logits. We report the comparison of our non-learned approach to non-learned TTA methods,Â i.e., we use Â Eq.Â (7) and Eq.Â (8) for Aggregation and Eq.Â (12) for Criterion. As shown inÂ Tab.Â A6, we do not find it beneficial to use non-learned TTA methods with the expanded policy. We directly compare our non-learned approach without integrating TTA,Â i.e., BğšğšğšŠ=1subscriptğµğšğšğšŠ1B_{\tt tta}=1italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_tta end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, to non-learned TTA methods. Our non-learned approach outperforms MeanTTA and MaxTTA without needing to increase the computation budget.

InÂ Tab.Â A7, we report the non-learned TTA methods with or without our non-learned approach using the standard policy. We observe that although Mean and MaxTTA work on a smaller budget, they do not scale with higher budgets. Our non-learned approach outperforms MeanTTA under most budget settings while MaxTTA is an ineffective non-learned TTA method.

Appendix A2 Additional results

A2.1 CIFAR10 & CIFAR100

We use the publicly available implementation from PyTorch CIFAR Models (https://github.com/chenyaofo/pytorch-cifar-models), which supports a variety of pre-trained models on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100. Specifically, there are 19 models in total, including ResNetÂ [18], VGGÂ [54], RepVGGÂ [12], MobileNetÂ [50], and ShuffleNetÂ [75] architectures. We report the experiments on all of them.

As in the main paper, we report the top-1 classification accuracy vs. the budget Bğš˜ğšğš›ğšœsubscriptğµğš˜ğšğš›ğšœB_{\tt ours}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT typewriter_ours end_POSTSUBSCRIPT inÂ Fig.Â A1 andÂ Fig.Â A2 for CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 respectively. On both CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets, we observe significant improvement in almost all scenarios except for VGG models. The performances of VGG models initially improves in low-budget setting and start to deteriorate quickly when given more budget. We suspect it is due to the fact that all subsampling layers in vanilla VGG are comprised of max-pooling layers. The local maximum remains very similar in discarded activation thus different state provides little additional information.

A2.2 TIMM pretrained-weights on ImageNet

InÂ Fig.Â A3, we provide additional results on TIMMÂ [62] backbones. These additional backbones include MobileNetV3Â [19], Multi-scale ViT (MViTv2)Â [29], DenseNetÂ [22], VGGÂ [54], RepVGGÂ [12], DeiTÂ [58], CoaTÂ [68], ConvNeXTV2Â [35, 64], XCiTÂ [2], VOLOÂ [71], PvTV2Â [59, 60], EfficientformerÂ [30]. Specifically, we use these variants from TIMM: mobilenetv3_small_100 for MobileNetV3, mvitv2_tiny for MViTV2, densenet121 for DenseNet, vgg11_bn for VGG,
repvgg_a2 for RepVGG, deit_tiny_patch16_224 for DeiT, volo_d1_224 for VOLO, pvt_v2_b0 for PvTV2, coat_tiny for CoaT, convnextv2_tiny for CoaT, and efficientformer_l1 for Efficientformer.

We observe that our approach consistently leads to better performance in most architectures. Our procedure excels in ViT-like architectures where subsampling layers with large subsampling rates Rğ‘…Ritalic_R are used.

A2.3 Cityscapes and ADE20K

InÂ Fig.Â A4 and Â Fig.Â A5, we report additional results on Cityscapes and ADE20K semantic segmentation respectively. We plot out the performances on aAcc (mean accuracy of all pixel accuracy) and the mAcc (mean accuracy of each class accuracy) besides the mIoU score. We also provide additional results on more MMSegÂ [40] backbones and decoders. These additional architectures include MobileNetV3+LRASPPÂ [19], UNetÂ [49], SwinÂ [34], UperNetÂ [65], and TwinsÂ [9]. Specifically, we use these variants from MMSeg: M-V3-D8 for MobileNetV3, MiT-B0 for MiT, Twins-PCPVT-S for Twins, and Swin-T for Swin.

As can be seen, our approach consistently leads to better performance, especially on mIoU and aAcc, in all architectures. Additionally, we show that our test-time procedure can further improve the performance when TTA (horizontal-flip) is used.

A2.4 Additional comparison to anti-aliasing downsampling

To preserve the lost information from downsampling layers, a line of work, anti-aliased CNNÂ [73] inserts a max-blur-pool layer to the pooling layer. Here, we demonstrate that our approach is orthogonal to the anti-aliasing method.

We report the performance of our approach on anti-aliased CNNs inÂ Tab.Â A8. We conduct experiments using their pre-trained model and observe that applying our approach to anti-aliased CNNs also leads to consistent performance gain.

Finally, max-blur-pool replaces max-pooling layers in CNN and requires training the whole model parameters; it is unclear how to apply it to ViTs which use patch merging instead of max-pooling. Our approach is generic and can be applied to both CNN and ViTs at test time while only training our additional attention module.

A3.2 TTA policy

Standard policy. The standardÂ [52] TTA policy is composed of the following data transformations, Flip, Scale, and FiveCrop. A3.3 Computational settings

All experiments are conducted on a single NVIDIA A6000 GPU.

A3.4 Modified subsampling layers

InÂ Fig.Â A6, we illustrate an implementation trick for faster computation inÂ Alg.Â 1: line 10. By changing the stride of the subsampling layer from their original stride value Rğ‘…Ritalic_R to 1111, we can get all the R2superscriptğ‘…2R^{2}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT neighboring states (activations) in a single forward pass.

A3.5 Searching procedure

For TIMM implementation, some models, eg. DenseNet and ViT, have fewer (less than 4) subsampling layers. We do not limit the searching space (Alg.Â 1: line 8) for them in our experiments. Some models, eg. PvTV2, have a larger subsampling rate Rğ‘…Ritalic_R (=4absent4=4= 4 or 16) on the first subsampling layer than the rest. We do not exclude the first layer from the searching space (Alg.Â 1: line 8) for them in our experiments.

A3.6 Spatial alignment

For TIMM transformer-based backbones, the output of FÎ¸subscriptğ¹ğœƒF_{\theta}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has the shape of batch_size by token_length by channel_size. In order to perform our 2-dimensional spatial alignment, we reshape it to batch_size by sqrt(token_length) by sqrt(token_length) by channel_size if applicable.

For example, the output shape of ViT, XCiT, CoaT, and DeiT features are not composite numbers so we do not reshape them. To aggregate the result from different states, we aggregate on the logits instead.

Next, for both the upsampling and downsampling Resize inÂ Fig.Â 3 in the spatial alignment, we use the nearest interpolation.
